lines.text: Did you hear what I was playing, Lane?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I didn’t think it polite to listen, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: I’m sorry for that, for your sake. I don’t play accurately—any one can play accurately—but I play with wonderful expression. As far as the piano is concerned, sentiment is my forte. I keep science for Life.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: And, speaking of the science of Life, have you got the cucumber sandwiches cut for Lady Bracknell?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Oh! . . . by the way, Lane, I see from your book that on Thursday night, when Lord Shoreman and Mr. Worthing were dining with me, eight bottles of champagne are entered as having been consumed.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir; eight bottles and a pint.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Why is it that at a bachelor’s establishment the servants invariably drink the champagne? I ask merely for information.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I attribute it to the superior quality of the wine, sir. I have often observed that in married households the champagne is rarely of a first-rate brand.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Good heavens! Is marriage so demoralising as that?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I believe it is a very pleasant state, sir. I have had very little experience of it myself up to the present. I have only been married once. That was in consequence of a misunderstanding between myself and a young person.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: I don’t know that I am much interested in your family life, Lane.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: No, sir; it is not a very interesting subject. I never think of it myself.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Very natural, I am sure. That will do, Lane, thank you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Thank you, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Lane's views on marriage seem somewhat lax. Really, if the lower orders don’t set us a good example, what on earth is the use of them? They seem, as a class, to have absolutely no sense of moral responsibility.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Mr. Ernest Worthing.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: How are you, my dear Ernest? What brings you up to town?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, pleasure, pleasure! What else should bring one anywhere? Eating as usual, I see, Algy!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I believe it is customary in good society to take some slight refreshment at five o’clock. Where have you been since last Thursday?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: In the country.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: What on earth do you do there?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: When one is in town one amuses oneself. When one is in the country one amuses other people. It is excessively boring.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: And who are the people you amuse?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, neighbours, neighbours.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Got nice neighbours in your part of Shropshire?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Perfectly horrid! Never speak to one of them.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: How immensely you must amuse them!  By the way, Shropshire is your county, is it not?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Eh? Shropshire? Yes, of course. Hallo! Why all these cups? Why cucumber sandwiches? Why such reckless extravagance in one so young? Who is coming to tea?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh! merely Aunt Augusta and Gwendolen.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: How perfectly delightful!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, that is all very well; but I am afraid Aunt Augusta won’t quite approve of your being here.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: May I ask why?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My dear fellow, the way you flirt with Gwendolen is perfectly disgraceful. It is almost as bad as the way Gwendolen flirts with you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am in love with Gwendolen. I have come up to town expressly to propose to her.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I thought you had come up for pleasure? . . . I call that business.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: How utterly unromantic you are!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I really don’t see anything romantic in proposing. It is very romantic to be in love. But there is nothing romantic about a definite proposal. Why, one may be accepted. One usually is, I believe. Then the excitement is all over. The very essence of romance is uncertainty. If ever I get married, I’ll certainly try to forget the fact.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I have no doubt about that, dear Algy. The Divorce Court was specially invented for people whose memories are so curiously constituted.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh! there is no use speculating on that subject. Divorces are made in Heaven— Please don’t touch the cucumber sandwiches. They are ordered specially for Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, you have been eating them all the time.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That is quite a different matter. She is my aunt.  Have some bread and butter. The bread and butter is for Gwendolen. Gwendolen is devoted to bread and butter.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: And very good bread and butter it is too.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, my dear fellow, you need not eat as if you were going to eat it all. You behave as if you were married to her already. You are not married to her already, and I don’t think you ever will be.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Why on earth do you say that?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, in the first place girls never marry the men they flirt with. Girls don’t think it right.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that is nonsense!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It isn’t. It is a great truth. It accounts for the extraordinary number of bachelors that one sees all over the place. In the second place, I don’t give my consent.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Your consent!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My dear fellow, Gwendolen is my first cousin. And before I allow you to marry her, you will have to clear up the whole question of Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Cecily! What on earth do you mean? What do you mean, Algy, by Cecily! I don’t know any one of the name of Cecily.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Bring me that cigarette case Mr. Worthing left in the smoking-room the last time he dined here.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Do you mean to say you have had my cigarette case all this time? I wish to goodness you had let me know. I have been writing frantic letters to Scotland Yard about it. I was very nearly offering a large reward.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, I wish you would offer one. I happen to be more than usually hard up.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: There is no good offering a large reward now that the thing is found.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I think that is rather mean of you, Ernest, I must say.  However, it makes no matter, for, now that I look at the inscription inside, I find that the thing isn’t yours after all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Of course it’s mine.  You have seen me with it a hundred times, and you have no right whatsoever to read what is written inside. It is a very ungentlemanly thing to read a private cigarette case.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh! it is absurd to have a hard and fast rule about what one should read and what one shouldn’t. More than half of modern culture depends on what one shouldn’t read.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am quite aware of the fact, and I don’t propose to discuss modern culture. It isn’t the sort of thing one should talk of in private. I simply want my cigarette case back.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes; but this isn’t your cigarette case. This cigarette case is a present from some one of the name of Cecily, and you said you didn’t know any one of that name.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, if you want to know, Cecily happens to be my aunt.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Your aunt!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes. Charming old lady she is, too. Lives at Tunbridge Wells. Just give it back to me, Algy.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But why does she call herself little Cecily if she is your aunt and lives at Tunbridge Wells?  ‘From little Cecily with her fondest love.’
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear fellow, what on earth is there in that? Some aunts are tall, some aunts are not tall. That is a matter that surely an aunt may be allowed to decide for herself. You seem to think that every aunt should be exactly like your aunt! That is absurd! For Heaven’s sake give me back my cigarette case.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes. But why does your aunt call you her uncle? ‘From little Cecily, with her fondest love to her dear Uncle Jack.’ There is no objection, I admit, to an aunt being a small aunt, but why an aunt, no matter what her size may be, should call her own nephew her uncle, I can’t quite make out. Besides, your name isn’t Jack at all; it is Ernest.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It isn’t Ernest; it’s Jack.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You have always told me it was Ernest. I have introduced you to every one as Ernest. You answer to the name of Ernest. You look as if your name was Ernest. You are the most earnest-looking person I ever saw in my life. It is perfectly absurd your saying that your name isn’t Ernest. It’s on your cards. Here is one of them.  ‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany.’ I’ll keep this as a proof that your name is Ernest if ever you attempt to deny it to me, or to Gwendolen, or to any one else.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, my name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and the cigarette case was given to me in the country.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but that does not account for the fact that your small Aunt Cecily, who lives at Tunbridge Wells, calls you her dear uncle. Come, old boy, you had much better have the thing out at once.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear Algy, you talk exactly as if you were a dentist. It is very vulgar to talk like a dentist when one isn’t a dentist. It produces a false impression,
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, that is exactly what dentists always do. Now, go on! Tell me the whole thing. I may mention that I have always suspected you of being a confirmed and secret Bunburyist; and I am quite sure of it now.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Bunburyist? What on earth do you mean by a Bunburyist?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I’ll reveal to you the meaning of that incomparable expression as soon as you are kind enough to inform me why you are Ernest in town and Jack in the country.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, produce my cigarette case first.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Here it is.  Now produce your explanation, and pray make it improbable.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear fellow, there is nothing improbable about my explanation at all. In fact it’s perfectly ordinary. Old Mr. Thomas Cardew, who adopted me when I was a little boy, made me in his will guardian to his grand-daughter, Miss Cecily Cardew. Cecily, who addresses me as her uncle from motives of respect that you could not possibly appreciate, lives at my place in the country under the charge of her admirable governess, Miss Prism.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Where is that place in the country, by the way?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That is nothing to you, dear boy. You are not going to be invited . . . I may tell you candidly that the place is not in Shropshire.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I suspected that, my dear fellow! I have Bunburyed all over Shropshire on two separate occasions. Now, go on. Why are you Ernest in town and Jack in the country?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear Algy, I don’t know whether you will be able to understand my real motives. You are hardly serious enough. When one is placed in the position of guardian, one has to adopt a very high moral tone on all subjects. It’s one’s duty to do so. And as a high moral tone can hardly be said to conduce very much to either one’s health or one’s happiness, in order to get up to town I have always pretended to have a younger brother of the name of Ernest, who lives in the Albany, and gets into the most dreadful scrapes. That, my dear Algy, is the whole truth pure and simple.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The truth is rarely pure and never simple. Modern life would be very tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete impossibility!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That wouldn’t be at all a bad thing.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Literary criticism is not your forte, my dear fellow. Don’t try it. You should leave that to people who haven’t been at a University. They do it so well in the daily papers. What you really are is a Bunburyist. I was quite right in saying you were a Bunburyist. You are one of the most advanced Bunburyists I know.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: What on earth do you mean?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You have invented a very useful younger brother called Ernest, in order that you may be able to come up to town as often as you like. I have invented an invaluable permanent invalid called Bunbury, in order that I may be able to go down into the country whenever I choose. Bunbury is perfectly invaluable. If it wasn’t for Bunbury’s extraordinary bad health, for instance, I wouldn’t be able to dine with you at Willis’s to-night, for I have been really engaged to Aunt Augusta for more than a week.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I haven’t asked you to dine with me anywhere to-night.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I know. You are absurdly careless about sending out invitations. It is very foolish of you. Nothing annoys people so much as not receiving invitations.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You had much better dine with your Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I haven’t the smallest intention of doing anything of the kind. To begin with, I dined there on Monday, and once a week is quite enough to dine with one’s own relations. In the second place, whenever I do dine there I am always treated as a member of the family, and sent down with either no woman at all, or two. In the third place, I know perfectly well whom she will place me next to, to-night. She will place me next Mary Farquhar, who always flirts with her own husband across the dinner-table. That is not very pleasant. Indeed, it is not even decent . . . and that sort of thing is enormously on the increase. The amount of women in London who flirt with their own husbands is perfectly scandalous. It looks so bad. It is simply washing one’s clean linen in public. Besides, now that I know you to be a confirmed Bunburyist I naturally want to talk to you about Bunburying. I want to tell you the rules.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I’m not a Bunburyist at all. If Gwendolen accepts me, I am going to kill my brother, indeed I think I’ll kill him in any case. Cecily is a little too much interested in him. It is rather a bore. So I am going to get rid of Ernest. And I strongly advise you to do the same with Mr . . . with your invalid friend who has the absurd name.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Nothing will induce me to part with Bunbury, and if you ever get married, which seems to me extremely problematic, you will be very glad to know Bunbury. A man who marries without knowing Bunbury has a very tedious time of it.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That is nonsense. If I marry a charming girl like Gwendolen, and she is the only girl I ever saw in my life that I would marry, I certainly won’t want to know Bunbury.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Then your wife will. You don’t seem to realise, that in married life three is company and two is none.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That, my dear young friend, is the theory that the corrupt French Drama has been propounding for the last fifty years.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes; and that the happy English home has proved in half the time.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: For heaven’s sake, don’t try to be cynical. It’s perfectly easy to be cynical.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My dear fellow, it isn’t easy to be anything nowadays. There’s such a lot of beastly competition about.  Ah! that must be Aunt Augusta. Only relatives, or creditors, ever ring in that Wagnerian manner. Now, if I get her out of the way for ten minutes, so that you can have an opportunity for proposing to Gwendolen, may I dine with you to-night at Willis’s?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I suppose so, if you want to.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but you must be serious about it. I hate people who are not serious about meals. It is so shallow of them.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Good afternoon, dear Algernon, I hope you are behaving very well.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I’m feeling very well, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That’s not quite the same thing. In fact the two things rarely go together.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Dear me, you are smart!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am always smart! Am I not, Mr. Worthing?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: You’re quite perfect, Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh! I hope I am not that. It would leave no room for developments, and I intend to develop in many directions.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I’m sorry if we are a little late, Algernon, but I was obliged to call on dear Lady Harbury. I hadn’t been there since her poor husband’s death. I never saw a woman so altered; she looks quite twenty years younger. And now I’ll have a cup of tea, and one of those nice cucumber sandwiches you promised me.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Certainly, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Won’t you come and sit here, Gwendolen?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thanks, mamma, I’m quite comfortable where I am.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Good heavens! Lane! Why are there no cucumber sandwiches? I ordered them specially.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: There were no cucumbers in the market this morning, sir. I went down twice.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: No cucumbers!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: No, sir. Not even for ready money.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: That will do, Lane, thank you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Thank you, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: I am greatly distressed, Aunt Augusta, about there being no cucumbers, not even for ready money.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It really makes no matter, Algernon. I had some crumpets with Lady Harbury, who seems to me to be living entirely for pleasure now.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I hear her hair has turned quite gold from grief.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It certainly has changed its colour. From what cause I, of course, cannot say.  Thank you. I’ve quite a treat for you to-night, Algernon. I am going to send you down with Mary Farquhar. She is such a nice woman, and so attentive to her husband. It’s delightful to watch them.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I am afraid, Aunt Augusta, I shall have to give up the pleasure of dining with you to-night after all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I hope not, Algernon. It would put my table completely out. Your uncle would have to dine upstairs. Fortunately he is accustomed to that.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: It is a great bore, and, I need hardly say, a terrible disappointment to me, but the fact is I have just had a telegram to say that my poor friend Bunbury is very ill again.  They seem to think I should be with him.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It is very strange. This Mr. Bunbury seems to suffer from curiously bad health.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes; poor Bunbury is a dreadful invalid.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, I must say, Algernon, that I think it is high time that Mr. Bunbury made up his mind whether he was going to live or to die. This shilly-shallying with the question is absurd. Nor do I in any way approve of the modern sympathy with invalids. I consider it morbid. Illness of any kind is hardly a thing to be encouraged in others. Health is the primary duty of life. I am always telling that to your poor uncle, but he never seems to take much notice . . . as far as any improvement in his ailment goes. I should be much obliged if you would ask Mr. Bunbury, from me, to be kind enough not to have a relapse on Saturday, for I rely on you to arrange my music for me. It is my last reception, and one wants something that will encourage conversation, particularly at the end of the season when every one has practically said whatever they had to say, which, in most cases, was probably not much.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I’ll speak to Bunbury, Aunt Augusta, if he is still conscious, and I think I can promise you he’ll be all right by Saturday. Of course the music is a great difficulty. You see, if one plays good music, people don’t listen, and if one plays bad music people don’t talk. But I’ll run over the programme I’ve drawn out, if you will kindly come into the next room for a moment.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Thank you, Algernon. It is very thoughtful of you.  I’m sure the programme will be delightful, after a few expurgations. French songs I cannot possibly allow. People always seem to think that they are improper, and either look shocked, which is vulgar, or laugh, which is worse. But German sounds a thoroughly respectable language, and indeed, I believe is so. Gwendolen, you will accompany me.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Certainly, mamma.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Charming day it has been, Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Pray don’t talk to me about the weather, Mr. Worthing. Whenever people talk to me about the weather, I always feel quite certain that they mean something else. And that makes me so nervous.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I do mean something else.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I thought so. In fact, I am never wrong.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: And I would like to be allowed to take advantage of Lady Bracknell’s temporary absence . . .
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I would certainly advise you to do so. Mamma has a way of coming back suddenly into a room that I have often had to speak to her about.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Miss Fairfax, ever since I met you I have admired you more than any girl . . . I have ever met since . . . I met you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, I am quite well aware of the fact. And I often wish that in public, at any rate, you had been more demonstrative. For me you have always had an irresistible fascination. Even before I met you I was far from indifferent to you.  We live, as I hope you know, Mr Worthing, in an age of ideals. The fact is constantly mentioned in the more expensive monthly magazines, and has reached the provincial pulpits, I am told; and my ideal has always been to love some one of the name of Ernest. There is something in that name that inspires absolute confidence. The moment Algernon first mentioned to me that he had a friend called Ernest, I knew I was destined to love you.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: You really love me, Gwendolen?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Passionately!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Darling! You don’t know how happy you’ve made me.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My own Ernest!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: But you don’t really mean to say that you couldn’t love me if my name wasn’t Ernest?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But your name is Ernest.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Yes, I know it is. But supposing it was something else? Do you mean to say you couldn’t love me then?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Ah! that is clearly a metaphysical speculation, and like most metaphysical speculations has very little reference at all to the actual facts of real life, as we know them.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Personally, darling, to speak quite candidly, I don’t much care about the name of Ernest . . . I don’t think the name suits me at all.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It suits you perfectly. It is a divine name. It has a music of its own. It produces vibrations.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Well, really, Gwendolen, I must say that I think there are lots of other much nicer names. I think Jack, for instance, a charming name.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Jack? . . . No, there is very little music in the name Jack, if any at all, indeed. It does not thrill. It produces absolutely no vibrations . . . I have known several Jacks, and they all, without exception, were more than usually plain. Besides, Jack is a notorious domesticity for John! And I pity any woman who is married to a man called John. She would probably never be allowed to know the entrancing pleasure of a single moment’s solitude. The only really safe name is Ernest
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen, I must get christened at once—I mean we must get married at once. There is no time to be lost.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Married, Mr. Worthing?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Well . . . surely. You know that I love you, and you led me to believe, Miss Fairfax, that you were not absolutely indifferent to me.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I adore you. But you haven’t proposed to me yet. Nothing has been said at all about marriage. The subject has not even been touched on.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Well . . . may I propose to you now?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I think it would be an admirable opportunity. And to spare you any possible disappointment, Mr. Worthing, I think it only fair to tell you quite frankly before-hand that I am fully determined to accept you.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, Mr. Worthing, what have you got to say to me?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: You know what I have got to say to you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but you don’t say it.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen, will you marry me?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Of course I will, darling. How long you have been about it! I am afraid you have had very little experience in how to propose.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My own one, I have never loved any one in the world but you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but men often propose for practice. I know my brother Gerald does. All my girl-friends tell me so. What wonderfully blue eyes you have, Ernest! They are quite, quite, blue. I hope you will always look at me just like that, especially when there are other people present.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Mr. Worthing! Rise, sir, from this semi-recumbent posture. It is most indecorous.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Mamma!  I must beg you to retire. This is no place for you. Besides, Mr. Worthing has not quite finished yet.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Finished what, may I ask?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I am engaged to Mr. Worthing, mamma.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Pardon me, you are not engaged to any one. When you do become engaged to some one, I, or your father, should his health permit him, will inform you of the fact. An engagement should come on a young girl as a surprise, pleasant or unpleasant, as the case may be. It is hardly a matter that she could be allowed to arrange for herself . . . And now I have a few questions to put to you, Mr. Worthing. While I am making these inquiries, you, Gwendolen, will wait for me below in the carriage.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Mamma!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: In the carriage, Gwendolen!  Gwendolen, the carriage!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, mamma.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: You can take a seat, Mr. Worthing.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thank you, Lady Bracknell, I prefer standing.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I feel bound to tell you that you are not down on my list of eligible young men, although I have the same list as the dear Duchess of Bolton has. We work together, in fact. However, I am quite ready to enter your name, should your answers be what a really affectionate mother requires. Do you smoke?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Well, yes, I must admit I smoke.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am glad to hear it. A man should always have an occupation of some kind. There are far too many idle men in London as it is. How old are you?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Twenty-nine.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A very good age to be married at. I have always been of opinion that a man who desires to get married should know either everything or nothing. Which do you know?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I know nothing, Lady Bracknell.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am pleased to hear it. I do not approve of anything that tampers with natural ignorance. Ignorance is like a delicate exotic fruit; touch it and the bloom is gone. The whole theory of modern education is radically unsound. Fortunately in England, at any rate, education produces no effect whatsoever. If it did, it would prove a serious danger to the upper classes, and probably lead to acts of violence in Grosvenor Square. What is your income?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Between seven and eight thousand a year.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: In land, or in investments?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: In investments, chiefly.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That is satisfactory. What between the duties expected of one during one’s lifetime, and the duties exacted from one after one’s death, land has ceased to be either a profit or a pleasure. It gives one position, and prevents one from keeping it up. That’s all that can be said about land.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I have a country house with some land, of course, attached to it, about fifteen hundred acres, I believe; but I don’t depend on that for my real income. In fact, as far as I can make out, the poachers are the only people who make anything out of it.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A country house! How many bedrooms? Well, that point can be cleared up afterwards. You have a town house, I hope? A girl with a simple, unspoiled nature, like Gwendolen, could hardly be expected to reside in the country.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Well, I own a house in Belgrave Square, but it is let by the year to Lady Bloxham. Of course, I can get it back whenever I like, at six months’ notice.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Lady Bloxham? I don’t know her.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Oh, she goes about very little. She is a lady considerably advanced in years.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Ah, nowadays that is no guarantee of respectability of character. What number in Belgrave Square?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: The unfashionable side. I thought there was something. However, that could easily be altered.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Do you mean the fashion, or the side?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Both, if necessary, I presume. What are your polities?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Well, I am afraid I really have none. I am a Liberal Unionist.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh, they count as Tories. They dine with us. Or come in the evening, at any rate. Now to minor matters. Are your parents living?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I have lost both my parents.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: To lose one parent, Mr. Worthing, may be regarded as a misfortune; to lose both looks like carelessness. Who was your father? He was evidently a man of some wealth. Was he born in what the Radical papers call the purple of commerce, or did he rise from the ranks of the aristocracy?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I am afraid I really don’t know. The fact is, Lady Bracknell, I said I had lost my parents. It would be nearer the truth to say that my parents seem to have lost me . . . I don’t actually know who I am by birth. I was . . . well, I was found.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Found!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: The late Mr. Thomas Cardew, an old gentleman of a very charitable and kindly disposition, found me, and gave me the name of Worthing, because he happened to have a first-class ticket for Worthing in his pocket at the time. Worthing is a place in Sussex. It is a seaside resort.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Where did the charitable gentleman who had a first-class ticket for this seaside resort find you?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: In a hand-bag.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A hand-bag?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, Lady Bracknell. I was in a hand-bag—a somewhat large, black leather hand-bag, with handles to it—an ordinary hand-bag in fact.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: In what locality did this Mr. James, or Thomas, Cardew come across this ordinary hand-bag?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: In the cloak-room at Victoria Station. It was given to him in mistake for his own.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The cloak-room at Victoria Station?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes. The Brighton line.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The line is immaterial. Mr. Worthing, I confess I feel somewhat bewildered by what you have just told me. To be born, or at any rate bred, in a hand-bag, whether it had handles or not, seems to me to display a contempt for the ordinary decencies of family life that reminds one of the worst excesses of the French Revolution. And I presume you know what that unfortunate movement led to? As for the particular locality in which the hand-bag was found, a cloak-room at a railway station might serve to conceal a social indiscretion—has probably, indeed, been used for that purpose before now-but it could hardly be regarded as an assured basis for a recognised position in good society.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: May I ask you then what you would advise me to do? I need hardly say I would do anything in the world to ensure Gwendolen’s happiness.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I would strongly advise you, Mr. Worthing, to try and acquire some relations as soon as possible, and to make a definite effort to produce at any rate one parent, of either sex, before the season is quite over.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Well, I don’t see how I could possibly manage to do that. I can produce the hand-bag at any moment. It is in my dressing-room at home. I really think that should satisfy you, Lady Bracknell.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Me, sir! What has it to do with me? You can hardly imagine that I and Lord Bracknell would dream of allowing our only daughter—a girl brought up with the utmost care—to marry into a cloak-room, and form an alliance with a parcel? Good morning, Mr. Worthing!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Good morning!  For goodness’ sake don’t play that ghastly tune, Algy. How idiotic you are!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Didn’t it go off all right, old boy? You don’t mean to say Gwendolen refused you? I know it is a way she has. She is always refusing people. I think it is most ill-natured of her.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, Gwendolen is as right as a trivet. As far as she is concerned, we are engaged. Her mother is perfectly unbearable. Never met such a Gorgon . . . I don’t really know what a Gorgon is like, but I am quite sure that Lady Bracknell is one. In any case, she is a monster, without being a myth, which is rather unfair . . . I beg your pardon, Algy, I suppose I shouldn’t talk about your own aunt in that way before you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My dear boy, I love hearing my relations abused. It is the only thing that makes me put up with them at all. Relations are simply a tedious pack of people, who haven’t got the remotest knowledge of how to live, nor the smallest instinct about when to die.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that is nonsense!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It isn’t!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, I won’t argue about the matter. You always want to argue about things.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That is exactly what things were originally made for.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Upon my word, if I thought that, I’d shoot myself . . .  You don’t think there is any chance of Gwendolen becoming like her mother in about a hundred and fifty years, do you, Algy?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man does. That’s his.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Is that clever?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It is perfectly phrased! and quite as true as any observation in civilised life should be.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am sick to death of cleverness. Everybody is clever nowadays. You can’t go anywhere without meeting clever people. The thing has become an absolute public nuisance. I wish to goodness we had a few fools left.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: We have.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I should extremely like to meet them. What do they talk about?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The fools? Oh! about the clever people, of course.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: What fools!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest in town, and Jack in the country?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear fellow, the truth isn’t quite the sort of thing one tells to a nice, sweet, refined girl. What extraordinary ideas you have about the way to behave to a woman!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The only way to behave to a woman is to make love to her, if she is pretty, and to some one else, if she is plain.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that is nonsense.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: What about your brother? What about the profligate Ernest?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, before the end of the week I shall have got rid of him. I’ll say he died in Paris of apoplexy. Lots of people die of apoplexy, quite suddenly, don’t they?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but it’s hereditary, my dear fellow. It’s a sort of thing that runs in families. You had much better say a severe chill.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You are sure a severe chill isn’t hereditary, or anything of that kind?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Of course it isn’t!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Very well, then. My poor brother Ernest to carried off suddenly, in Paris, by a severe chill. That gets rid of him.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But I thought you said that . . . Miss Cardew was a little too much interested in your poor brother Ernest? Won’t she feel his loss a good deal?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that is all right. Cecily is not a silly romantic girl, I am glad to say. She has got a capital appetite, goes long walks, and pays no attention at all to her lessons.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I would rather like to see Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I will take very good care you never do. She is excessively pretty, and she is only just eighteen.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Have you told Gwendolen yet that you have an excessively pretty ward who is only just eighteen?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh! one doesn’t blurt these things out to people. Cecily and Gwendolen are perfectly certain to be extremely great friends. I’ll bet you anything you like that half an hour after they have met, they will be calling each other sister.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Women only do that when they have called each other a lot of other things first. Now, my dear boy, if we want to get a good table at Willis’s, we really must go and dress. Do you know it is nearly seven?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh! It always is nearly seven.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, I’m hungry.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I never knew you when you weren’t . . .
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: What shall we do after dinner? Go to a theatre?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh no! I loathe listening.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, let us go to the Club?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, no! I hate talking.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, we might trot round to the Empire at ten?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, no! I can’t bear looking at things. It is so silly.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, what shall we do?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Nothing!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It is awfully hard work doing nothing. However, I don’t mind hard work where there is no definite object of any kind.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Gwendolen, upon my word!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Algy, kindly turn your back. I have something very particular to say to Mr. Worthing.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Really, Gwendolen, I don’t think I can allow this at all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Algy, you always adopt a strictly immoral attitude towards life. You are not quite old enough to do that.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My own darling!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Ernest, we may never be married. From the expression on mamma’s face I fear we never shall. Few parents nowadays pay any regard to what their children say to them. The old-fashioned respect for the young is fast dying out. Whatever influence I ever had over mamma, I lost at the age of three. But although she may prevent us from becoming man and wife, and I may marry some one else, and marry often, nothing that she can possibly do can alter my eternal devotion to you.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Dear Gwendolen!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The story of your romantic origin, as related to me by mamma, with unpleasing comments, has naturally stirred the deeper fibres of my nature. Your Christian name has an irresistible fascination. The simplicity of your character makes you exquisitely incomprehensible to me. Your town address at the Albany I have. What is your address in the country?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: The Manor House, Woolton, Hertfordshire.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: There is a good postal service, I suppose? It may be necessary to do something desperate. That of course will require serious consideration. I will communicate with you daily.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My own one!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: How long do you remain in town?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Till Monday.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Good! Algy, you may turn round now.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Thanks, I’ve turned round already.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You may also ring the bell.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: You will let me see you to your carriage, my own darling?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Certainly.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I will see Miss Fairfax out.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: A glass of sherry, Lane.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: To-morrow, Lane, I’m going Bunburying.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: I shall probably not be back till Monday. You can put up my dress clothes, my smoking jacket, and all the Bunbury suits . . .
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: I hope to-morrow will be a fine day, Lane.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It never is, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: Lane, you’re a perfect pessimist.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I do my best to give satisfaction, sir.
lines.name: Lane

lines.text: There’s a sensible, intellectual girl! the only girl I ever cared for in my life.  What on earth are you so amused at?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh, I’m a little anxious about poor Bunbury, that is all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: If you don’t take care, your friend Bunbury will get you into a serious scrape some day.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I love scrapes. They are the only things that are never serious.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that’s nonsense, Algy. You never talk anything but nonsense.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Nobody ever does.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Cecily, Cecily! Surely such a utilitarian occupation as the watering of flowers is rather Moulton’s duty than yours? Especially at a moment when intellectual pleasures await you. Your German grammar is on the table. Pray open it at page fifteen. We will repeat yesterday’s lesson.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But I don’t like German. It isn’t at all a becoming language. I know perfectly well that I look quite plain after my German lesson.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Child, you know how anxious your guardian is that you should improve yourself in every way. He laid particular stress on your German, as he was leaving for town yesterday. Indeed, he always lays stress on your German when he is leaving for town.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Dear Uncle Jack is so very serious! Sometimes he is so serious that I think he cannot be quite well.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Your guardian enjoys the best of health, and his gravity of demeanour is especially to be commended in one so comparatively young as he is. I know no one who has a higher sense of duty and responsibility.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I suppose that is why he often looks a little bored when we three are together.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily! I am surprised at you. Mr. Worthing has many troubles in his life. Idle merriment and triviality would be out of place in his conversation. You must remember his constant anxiety about that unfortunate young man his brother.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I wish Uncle Jack would allow that unfortunate young man, his brother, to come down here sometimes. We might have a good influence over him, Miss Prism. I am sure you certainly would. You know German, and geology, and things of that kind influence a man very much.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I do not think that even I could produce any effect on a character that according to his own brother’s admission is irretrievably weak and vacillating. Indeed I am not sure that I would desire to reclaim him. I am not in favour of this modern mania for turning bad people into good people at a moment’s notice. As a man sows so let him reap. You must put away your diary, Cecily. I really don’t see why you should keep a diary at all.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I keep a diary in order to enter the wonderful secrets of my life. If I didn’t write them down, I should probably forget all about them.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Memory, my dear Cecily, is the diary that we all carry about with us.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Yes, but it usually chronicles the things that have never happened, and couldn’t possibly have happened. I believe that Memory is responsible for nearly all the three-volume novels that Mudie sends us.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Do not speak slightingly of the three-volume novel, Cecily. I wrote one myself in earlier days.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Did you really, Miss Prism? How wonderfully clever you are! I hope it did not end happily? I don’t like novels that end happily. They depress me so much.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: The good ended happily, and the bad unhappily. That is what Fiction means.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I suppose so. But it seems very unfair. And was your novel ever published?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Alas! no. The manuscript unfortunately was abandoned.  I use the word in the sense of lost or mislaid. To your work, child, these speculations are profitless.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But I see dear Dr. Chasuble coming up through the garden.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Dr. Chasuble! This is indeed a pleasure.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: And how are we this morning? Miss Prism, you are, I trust, well?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Miss Prism has just been complaining of a slight headache. I think it would do her so much good to have a short stroll with you in the Park, Dr. Chasuble.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily, I have not mentioned anything about a headache.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: No, dear Miss Prism, I know that, but I felt instinctively that you had a headache. Indeed I was thinking about that, and not about my German lesson, when the Rector came in.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I hope, Cecily, you are not inattentive.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Oh, I am afraid I am.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: That is strange. Were I fortunate enough to be Miss Prism’s pupil, I would hang upon her lips.  I spoke metaphorically.—My metaphor was drawn from bees. Ahem! Mr. Worthing, I suppose, has not returned from town yet?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: We do not expect him till Monday afternoon.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Ah yes, he usually likes to spend his Sunday in London. He is not one of those whose sole aim is enjoyment, as, by all accounts, that unfortunate young man his brother seems to be. But I must not disturb Egeria and her pupil any longer.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Egeria? My name is Lætitia, Doctor.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: A classical allusion merely, drawn from the Pagan authors. I shall see you both no doubt at Evensong?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I think, dear Doctor, I will have a stroll with you. I find I have a headache after all, and a walk might do it good.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: With pleasure, Miss Prism, with pleasure. We might go as far as the schools and back.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: That would be delightful. Cecily, you will read your Political Economy in my absence. The chapter on the Fall of the Rupee you may omit. It is somewhat too sensational. Even these metallic problems have their melodramatic side.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Horrid Political Economy! Horrid Geography! Horrid, horrid German!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: . Mr. Ernest Worthing has just driven over from the station. He has brought his luggage with him.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: ‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany, W.’ Uncle Jack’s brother! Did you tell him Mr. Worthing was in town?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: . Yes, Miss. He seemed very much disappointed. I mentioned that you and Miss Prism were in the garden. He said he was anxious to speak to you privately for a moment.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Ask Mr. Ernest Worthing to come here. I suppose you had better talk to the housekeeper about a room for him.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: . Yes, Miss.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: I have never met any really wicked person before. I feel rather frightened. I am so afraid he will look just like every one else.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You are my little cousin Cecily, I’m sure.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You are under some strange mistake. I am not little. In fact, I believe I am more than usually tall for my age.  But I am your cousin Cecily. You, I see from your card, are Uncle Jack’s brother, my cousin Ernest, my wicked cousin Ernest.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh! I am not really wicked at all, cousin Cecily. You mustn’t think that I am wicked.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: If you are not, then you have certainly been deceiving us all in a very inexcusable manner. I hope you have not been leading a double life, pretending to be wicked and being really good all the time. That would be hypocrisy.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh! Of course I have been rather reckless.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am glad to hear it.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: In fact, now you mention the subject, I have been very bad in my own small way.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t think you should be so proud of that, though I am sure it must have been very pleasant.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: It is much pleasanter being here with you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I can’t understand how you are here at all. Uncle Jack won’t be back till Monday afternoon.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: That is a great disappointment. I am obliged to go up by the first train on Monday morning. I have a business appointment that I am anxious . . . to miss?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Couldn’t you miss it anywhere but in London?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: No: the appointment is in London.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, I know, of course, how important it is not to keep a business engagement, if one wants to retain any sense of the beauty of life, but still I think you had better wait till Uncle Jack arrives. I know he wants to speak to you about your emigrating.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: About my what?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Your emigrating. He has gone up to buy your outfit.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I certainly wouldn’t let Jack buy my outfit. He has no taste in neckties at all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t think you will require neckties. Uncle Jack is sending you to Australia.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Australia! I’d sooner die.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, he said at dinner on Wednesday night, that you would have to choose between this world, the next world, and Australia.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh, well! The accounts I have received of Australia and the next world, are not particularly encouraging. This world is good enough for me, cousin Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, but are you good enough for it?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I’m afraid I’m not that. That is why I want you to reform me. You might make that your mission, if you don’t mind, cousin Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I’m afraid I’ve no time, this afternoon.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Well, would you mind my reforming myself this afternoon?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It is rather Quixotic of you. But I think you should try.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I will. I feel better already.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You are looking a little worse.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: That is because I am hungry.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: How thoughtless of me. I should have remembered that when one is going to lead an entirely new life, one requires regular and wholesome meals. Won’t you come in?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Thank you. Might I have a buttonhole first? I never have any appetite unless I have a buttonhole first.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: A Marechal Niel?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: No, I’d sooner have a pink rose.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Why?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Because you are like a pink rose, Cousin Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t think it can be right for you to talk to me like that. Miss Prism never says such things to me.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Then Miss Prism is a short-sighted old lady.  You are the prettiest girl I ever saw.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Miss Prism says that all good looks are a snare.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: They are a snare that every sensible man would like to be caught in.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, I don’t think I would care to catch a sensible man. I shouldn’t know what to talk to him about.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You are too much alone, dear Dr. Chasuble. You should get married. A misanthrope I can understand—a womanthrope, never!
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Believe me, I do not deserve so neologistic a phrase. The precept as well as the practice of the Primitive Church was distinctly against matrimony.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: That is obviously the reason why the Primitive Church has not lasted up to the present day. And you do not seem to realise, dear Doctor, that by persistently remaining single, a man converts himself into a permanent public temptation. Men should be more careful; this very celibacy leads weaker vessels astray.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But is a man not equally attractive when married?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: No married man is ever attractive except to his wife.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: And often, I’ve been told, not even to her.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: That depends on the intellectual sympathies of the woman. Maturity can always be depended on. Ripeness can be trusted. Young women are green.  I spoke horticulturally. My metaphor was drawn from fruits. But where is Cecily?
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Perhaps she followed us to the schools.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Mr. Worthing!
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Mr. Worthing?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: This is indeed a surprise. We did not look for you till Monday afternoon.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I have returned sooner than I expected. Dr. Chasuble, I hope you are well?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Dear Mr. Worthing, I trust this garb of woe does not betoken some terrible calamity?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: My brother.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: More shameful debts and extravagance?
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Still leading his life of pleasure?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Dead!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Your brother Ernest dead?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Quite dead.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: What a lesson for him! I trust he will profit by it.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Mr. Worthing, I offer you my sincere condolence. You have at least the consolation of knowing that you were always the most generous and forgiving of brothers.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Poor Ernest! He had many faults, but it is a sad, sad blow.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Very sad indeed. Were you with him at the end?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: No. He died abroad; in Paris, in fact. I had a telegram last night from the manager of the Grand Hotel.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Was the cause of death mentioned?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: A severe chill, it seems.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: As a man sows, so shall he reap.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Charity, dear Miss Prism, charity! None of us are perfect. I myself am peculiarly susceptible to draughts. Will the interment take place here?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: No. He seems to have expressed a desire to be buried in Paris.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: In Paris!  I fear that hardly points to any very serious state of mind at the last. You would no doubt wish me to make some slight allusion to this tragic domestic affliction next Sunday.  My sermon on the meaning of the manna in the wilderness can be adapted to almost any occasion, joyful, or, as in the present case, distressing.  I have preached it at harvest celebrations, christenings, confirmations, on days of humiliation and festal days. The last time I delivered it was in the Cathedral, as a charity sermon on behalf of the Society for the Prevention of Discontent among the Upper Orders. The Bishop, who was present, was much struck by some of the analogies I drew.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Ah! that reminds me, you mentioned christenings I think, Dr. Chasuble? I suppose you know how to christen all right?  I mean, of course, you are continually christening, aren’t you?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It is, I regret to say, one of the Rector’s most constant duties in this parish. I have often spoken to the poorer classes on the subject. But they don’t seem to know what thrift is.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But is there any particular infant in whom you are interested, Mr. Worthing? Your brother was, I believe, unmarried, was he not?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Oh yes.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: People who live entirely for pleasure usually are.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But it is not for any child, dear Doctor. I am very fond of children. No! the fact is, I would like to be christened myself, this afternoon, if you have nothing better to do.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But surely, Mr. Worthing, you have been christened already?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I don’t remember anything about it.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But have you any grave doubts on the subject?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I certainly intend to have. Of course I don’t know if the thing would bother you in any way, or if you think I am a little too old now.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Not at all. The sprinkling, and, indeed, the immersion of adults is a perfectly canonical practice.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Immersion!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You need have no apprehensions. Sprinkling is all that is necessary, or indeed I think advisable. Our weather is so changeable. At what hour would you wish the ceremony performed?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Oh, I might trot round about five if that would suit you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Perfectly, perfectly! In fact I have two similar ceremonies to perform at that time. A case of twins that occurred recently in one of the outlying cottages on your own estate. Poor Jenkins the carter, a most hard-working man.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Oh! I don’t see much fun in being christened along with other babies. It would be childish. Would half-past five do?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Admirably! Admirably!  And now, dear Mr. Worthing, I will not intrude any longer into a house of sorrow. I would merely beg you not to be too much bowed down by grief. What seem to us bitter trials are often blessings in disguise.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: This seems to me a blessing of an extremely obvious kind.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Uncle Jack! Oh, I am pleased to see you back. But what horrid clothes you have got on! Do go and change them.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily!
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: My child! my child!
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: What is the matter, Uncle Jack? Do look happy! You look as if you had toothache, and I have got such a surprise for you. Who do you think is in the dining-room? Your brother!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Who?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Your brother Ernest. He arrived about half an hour ago.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: What nonsense! I haven’t got a brother.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Oh, don’t say that. However badly he may have behaved to you in the past he is still your brother. You couldn’t be so heartless as to disown him. I’ll tell him to come out. And you will shake hands with him, won’t you, Uncle Jack?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: These are very joyful tidings.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: After we had all been resigned to his loss, his sudden return seems to me peculiarly distressing.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: My brother is in the dining-room? I don’t know what it all means. I think it is perfectly absurd.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Good heavens!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Brother John, I have come down from town to tell you that I am very sorry for all the trouble I have given you, and that I intend to lead a better life in the future.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Uncle Jack, you are not going to refuse your own brother’s hand?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Nothing will induce me to take his hand. I think his coming down here disgraceful. He knows perfectly well why.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Uncle Jack, do be nice. There is some good in every one. Ernest has just been telling me about his poor invalid friend Mr. Bunbury whom he goes to visit so often. And surely there must be much good in one who is kind to an invalid, and leaves the pleasures of London to sit by a bed of pain.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh! he has been talking about Bunbury, has he?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, he has told me all about poor Mr. Bunbury, and his terrible state of health.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Bunbury! Well, I won’t have him talk to you about Bunbury or about anything else. It is enough to drive one perfectly frantic.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Of course I admit that the faults were all on my side. But I must say that I think that Brother John’s coldness to me is peculiarly painful. I expected a more enthusiastic welcome, especially considering it is the first time I have come here.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Uncle Jack, if you don’t shake hands with Ernest I will never forgive you.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Never forgive me?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Never, never, never!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Well, this is the last time I shall ever do it.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It’s pleasant, is it not, to see so perfect a reconciliation? I think we might leave the two brothers together.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Cecily, you will come with us.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Certainly, Miss Prism. My little task of reconciliation is over.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You have done a beautiful action to-day, dear child.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: We must not be premature in our judgments.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I feel very happy.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You young scoundrel, Algy, you must get out of this place as soon as possible. I don’t allow any Bunburying here.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: . I have put Mr. Ernest’s things in the room next to yours, sir. I suppose that is all right?
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: What?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Mr. Ernest’s luggage, sir. I have unpacked it and put it in the room next to your own.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: His luggage?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, sir. Three portmanteaus, a dressing-case, two hat-boxes, and a large luncheon-basket.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: I am afraid I can’t stay more than a week this time.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Merriman, order the dog-cart at once. Mr. Ernest has been suddenly called back to town.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: What a fearful liar you are, Jack. I have not been called back to town at all.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, you have.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I haven’t heard any one call me.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Your duty as a gentleman calls you back.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My duty as a gentleman has never interfered with my pleasures in the smallest degree.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I can quite understand that.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, Cecily is a darling.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You are not to talk of Miss Cardew like that. I don’t like it.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, I don’t like your clothes. You look perfectly ridiculous in them. Why on earth don’t you go up and change? It is perfectly childish to be in deep mourning for a man who is actually staying for a whole week with you in your house as a guest. I call it grotesque.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You are certainly not staying with me for a whole week as a guest or anything else. You have got to leave . . . by the four-five train.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I certainly won’t leave you so long as you are in mourning. It would be most unfriendly. If I were in mourning you would stay with me, I suppose. I should think it very unkind if you didn’t.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, will you go if I change my clothes?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, if you are not too long. I never saw anybody take so long to dress, and with such little result.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, at any rate, that is better than being always over-dressed as you are.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: If I am occasionally a little over-dressed, I make up for it by being always immensely over-educated.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Your vanity is ridiculous, your conduct an outrage, and your presence in my garden utterly absurd. However, you have got to catch the four-five, and I hope you will have a pleasant journey back to town. This Bunburying, as you call it, has not been a great success for you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I think it has been a great success. I’m in love with Cecily, and that is everything.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, I merely came back to water the roses. I thought you were with Uncle Jack.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: He’s gone to order the dog-cart for me.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, is he going to take you for a nice drive?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: He’s going to send me away.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Then have we got to part?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I am afraid so. It’s a very painful parting.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It is always painful to part from people whom one has known for a very brief space of time. The absence of old friends one can endure with equanimity. But even a momentary separation from anyone to whom one has just been introduced is almost unbearable.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Thank you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: The dog-cart is at the door, sir.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: It can wait, Merriman for . . . five minutes.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes, Miss.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: I hope, Cecily, I shall not offend you if I state quite frankly and openly that you seem to me to be in every way the visible personification of absolute perfection.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I think your frankness does you great credit, Ernest. If you will allow me, I will copy your remarks into my diary.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Do you really keep a diary? I’d give anything to look at it. May I?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh no.  You see, it is simply a very young girl’s record of her own thoughts and impressions, and consequently meant for publication. When it appears in volume form I hope you will order a copy. But pray, Ernest, don’t stop. I delight in taking down from dictation. I have reached ‘absolute perfection’. You can go on. I am quite ready for more.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Ahem! Ahem!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, don’t cough, Ernest. When one is dictating one should speak fluently and not cough. Besides, I don’t know how to spell a cough.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily, ever since I first looked upon your wonderful and incomparable beauty, I have dared to love you wildly, passionately, devotedly, hopelessly.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t think that you should tell me that you love me wildly, passionately, devotedly, hopelessly. Hopelessly doesn’t seem to make much sense, does it?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: The dog-cart is waiting, sir.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Tell it to come round next week, at the same hour.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, sir.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Uncle Jack would be very much annoyed if he knew you were staying on till next week, at the same hour.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh, I don’t care about Jack. I don’t care for anybody in the whole world but you. I love you, Cecily. You will marry me, won’t you?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You silly boy! Of course. Why, we have been engaged for the last three months.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: For the last three months?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, it will be exactly three months on Thursday.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: But how did we become engaged?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, ever since dear Uncle Jack first confessed to us that he had a younger brother who was very wicked and bad, you of course have formed the chief topic of conversation between myself and Miss Prism. And of course a man who is much talked about is always very attractive. One feels there must be something in him, after all. I daresay it was foolish of me, but I fell in love with you, Ernest.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Darling! And when was the engagement actually settled?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: On the 14th of February last. Worn out by your entire ignorance of my existence, I determined to end the matter one way or the other, and after a long struggle with myself I accepted you under this dear old tree here. The next day I bought this little ring in your name, and this is the little bangle with the true lover’s knot I promised you always to wear.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Did I give you this? It’s very pretty, isn’t it?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, you’ve wonderfully good taste, Ernest. It’s the excuse I’ve always given for your leading such a bad life. And this is the box in which I keep all your dear letters.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: My letters! But, my own sweet Cecily, I have never written you any letters.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You need hardly remind me of that, Ernest. I remember only too well that I was forced to write your letters for you. I wrote always three times a week, and sometimes oftener.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh, do let me read them, Cecily?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, I couldn’t possibly. They would make you far too conceited.  The three you wrote me after I had broken off the engagement are so beautiful, and so badly spelled, that even now I can hardly read them without crying a little.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: But was our engagement ever broken off?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Of course it was. On the 22nd of last March. You can see the entry if you like.  ‘To-day I broke off my engagement with Ernest. I feel it is better to do so. The weather still continues charming.’
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: But why on earth did you break it off? What had I done? I had done nothing at all. Cecily, I am very much hurt indeed to hear you broke it off. Particularly when the weather was so charming.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: It would hardly have been a really serious engagement if it hadn’t been broken off at least once. But I forgave you before the week was out.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: What a perfect angel you are, Cecily.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You dear romantic boy.  I hope your hair curls naturally, does it?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes, darling, with a little help from others.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I am so glad.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You’ll never break off our engagement again, Cecily?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t think I could break it off now that I have actually met you. Besides, of course, there is the question of your name.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes, of course.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: You must not laugh at me, darling, but it had always been a girlish dream of mine to love some one whose name was Ernest.  There is something in that name that seems to inspire absolute confidence. I pity any poor married woman whose husband is not called Ernest.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: But, my dear child, do you mean to say you could not love me if I had some other name?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: But what name?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh, any name you like—Algernon—for instance . . .
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: But I don’t like the name of Algernon.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Well, my own dear, sweet, loving little darling, I really can’t see why you should object to the name of Algernon. It is not at all a bad name. In fact, it is rather an aristocratic name. Half of the chaps who get into the Bankruptcy Court are called Algernon. But seriously, Cecily . . .  . . . if my name was Algy, couldn’t you love me?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I might respect you, Ernest, I might admire your character, but I fear that I should not be able to give you my undivided attention.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Ahem! Cecily!  Your Rector here is, I suppose, thoroughly experienced in the practice of all the rites and ceremonials of the Church?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, yes. Dr. Chasuble is a most learned man. He has never written a single book, so you can imagine how much he knows.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I must see him at once on a most important christening—I mean on most important business.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I shan’t be away more than half an hour.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Considering that we have been engaged since February the 14th, and that I only met you to-day for the first time, I think it is rather hard that you should leave me for so long a period as half an hour. Couldn’t you make it twenty minutes?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I’ll be back in no time.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: What an impetuous boy he is! I like his hair so much. I must enter his proposal in my diary.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: A Miss Fairfax has just called to see Mr. Worthing. On very important business, Miss Fairfax states.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Isn’t Mr. Worthing in his library?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Mr. Worthing went over in the direction of the Rectory some time ago.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Pray ask the lady to come out here; Mr. Worthing is sure to be back soon. And you can bring tea.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes, Miss.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Miss Fairfax! I suppose one of the many good elderly women who are associated with Uncle Jack in some of his philanthropic work in London. I don’t quite like women who are interested in philanthropic work. I think it is so forward of them.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Pray let me introduce myself to you. My name is Cecily Cardew.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Cecily Cardew?  What a very sweet name! Something tells me that we are going to be great friends. I like you already more than I can say. My first impressions of people are never wrong.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: How nice of you to like me so much after we have known each other such a comparatively short time. Pray sit down.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I may call you Cecily, may I not?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: With pleasure!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: And you will always call me Gwendolen, won’t you?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: If you wish.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Then that is all quite settled, is it not?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I hope so.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Perhaps this might be a favourable opportunity for my mentioning who I am. My father is Lord Bracknell. You have never heard of papa, I suppose?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I don’t think so.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Outside the family circle, papa, I am glad to say, is entirely unknown. I think that is quite as it should be. The home seems to me to be the proper sphere for the man. And certainly once a man begins to neglect his domestic duties he becomes painfully effeminate, does he not? And I don’t like that. It makes men so very attractive. Cecily, mamma, whose views on education are remarkably strict, has brought me up to be extremely short-sighted; it is part of her system; so do you mind my looking at you through my glasses?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh! not at all, Gwendolen. I am very fond of being looked at.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You are here on a short visit, I suppose.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh no! I live here.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Really? Your mother, no doubt, or some female relative of advanced years, resides here also?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh no! I have no mother, nor, in fact, any relations.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Indeed?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My dear guardian, with the assistance of Miss Prism, has the arduous task of looking after me.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Your guardian?
