lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Yes, I am Mr. Worthing’s ward.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Oh! It is strange he never mentioned to me that he had a ward. How secretive of him! He grows more interesting hourly. I am not sure, however, that the news inspires me with feelings of unmixed delight.  I am very fond of you, Cecily; I have liked you ever since I met you! But I am bound to state that now that I know that you are Mr. Worthing’s ward, I cannot help expressing a wish you were—well, just a little older than you seem to be—and not quite so very alluring in appearance. In fact, if I may speak candidly -
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Pray do! I think that whenever one has anything unpleasant to say, one should always be quite candid.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Well, to speak with perfect candour, Cecily, I wish that you were fully forty-two, and more than usually plain for your age. Ernest has a strong upright nature. He is the very soul of truth and honour. Disloyalty would be as impossible to him as deception. But even men of the noblest possible moral character are extremely susceptible to the influence of the physical charms of others. Modern, no less than Ancient History, supplies us with many most painful examples of what I refer to. If it were not so, indeed, History would be quite unreadable.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I beg your pardon, Gwendolen, did you say Ernest?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh, but it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is my guardian. It is his brother—his elder brother.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Ernest never mentioned to me that he had a brother.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I am sorry to say they have not been on good terms for a long time.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Ah! that accounts for it. And now that I think of it I have never heard any man mention his brother. The subject seems distasteful to most men. Cecily, you have lifted a load from my mind. I was growing almost anxious. It would have been terrible if any cloud had come across a friendship like ours, would it not? Of course you are quite, quite sure that it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is your guardian?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Quite sure.  In fact, I am going to be his.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I beg your pardon?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Dearest Gwendolen, there is no reason why I should make a secret of it to you. Our little county newspaper is sure to chronicle the fact next week. Mr. Ernest Worthing and I are engaged to be married.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: My darling Cecily, I think there must be some slight error. Mr. Ernest Worthing is engaged to me. The announcement will appear in the Morning Post on Saturday at the latest.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I am afraid you must be under some misconception. Ernest proposed to me exactly ten minutes ago.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: It is certainly very curious, for he asked me to be his wife yesterday afternoon at 5.30. If you would care to verify the incident, pray do so.  I never travel without my diary. One should always have something sensational to read in the train. I am so sorry, dear Cecily, if it is any disappointment to you, but I am afraid I have the prior claim.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: It would distress me more than I can tell you, dear Gwendolen, if it caused you any mental or physical anguish, but I feel bound to point out that since Ernest proposed to you he clearly has changed his mind.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: If the poor fellow has been entrapped into any foolish promise I shall consider it my duty to rescue him at once, and with a firm hand.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Whatever unfortunate entanglement my dear boy may have got into, I will never reproach him with it after we are married.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Do you allude to me, Miss Cardew, as an entanglement? You are presumptuous. On an occasion of this kind it becomes more than a moral duty to speak one’s mind. It becomes a pleasure.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Do you suggest, Miss Fairfax, that I entrapped Ernest into an engagement? How dare you? This is no time for wearing the shallow mask of manners. When I see a spade I call it a spade.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I am glad to say that I have never seen a spade. It is obvious that our social spheres have been widely different.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Shall I lay tea here as usual, Miss?
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Yes, as usual.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Are there many interesting walks in the vicinity, Miss Cardew?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh! yes! a great many. From the top of one of the hills quite close one can see five counties.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Five counties! I don’t think I should like that; I hate crowds.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I suppose that is why you live in town?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Quite a well-kept garden this is, Miss Cardew.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: So glad you like it, Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I had no idea there were any flowers in the country.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Oh, flowers are as common here, Miss Fairfax, as people are in London.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Personally I cannot understand how anybody manages to exist in the country, if anybody who is anybody does. The country always bores me to death.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Ah! This is what the newspapers call agricultural depression, is it not? I believe the aristocracy are suffering very much from it just at present. It is almost an epidemic amongst them, I have been told. May I offer you some tea, Miss Fairfax?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Thank you.  Detestable girl! But I require tea!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Sugar?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: No, thank you. Sugar is not fashionable any more.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Cake or bread and butter?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Bread and butter, please. Cake is rarely seen at the best houses nowadays.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Hand that to Miss Fairfax.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You have filled my tea with lumps of sugar, and though I asked most distinctly for bread and butter, you have given me cake. I am known for the gentleness of my disposition, and the extraordinary sweetness of my nature, but I warn you, Miss Cardew, you may go too far.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: To save my poor, innocent, trusting boy from the machinations of any other girl there are no lengths to which I would not go.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: From the moment I saw you I distrusted you. I felt that you were false and deceitful. I am never deceived in such matters. My first impressions of people are invariably right.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: It seems to me, Miss Fairfax, that I am trespassing on your valuable time. No doubt you have many other calls of a similar character to make in the neighbourhood.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Ernest! My own Ernest!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen! Darling!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A moment! May I ask if you are engaged to be married to this young lady?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: To dear little Cecily! Of course not! What could have put such an idea into your pretty little head?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Thank you. You may!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I knew there must be some misunderstanding, Miss Fairfax. The gentleman whose arm is at present round your waist is my guardian, Mr. John Worthing.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I beg your pardon?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: This is Uncle Jack.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Jack! Oh!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Here is Ernest.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: My own love!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: A moment, Ernest! May I ask you—are you engaged to be married to this young lady?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: To what young lady? Good heavens! Gwendolen!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes! to good heavens, Gwendolen, I mean to Gwendolen.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Of course not! What could have put such an idea into your pretty little head?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Thank you.  You may.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I felt there was some slight error, Miss Cardew. The gentleman who is now embracing you is my cousin, Mr. Algernon Moncrieff.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Algernon Moncrieff! Oh!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Are you called Algernon?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I cannot deny it.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Is your name really John?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I could deny it if I liked. I could deny anything if I liked. But my name certainly is John. It has been John for years.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A gross deception has been practised on both of us.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: My poor wounded Cecily!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My sweet wronged Gwendolen!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You will call me sister, will you not?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: There is just one question I would like to be allowed to ask my guardian.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: An admirable idea! Mr. Worthing, there is just one question I would like to be permitted to put to you. Where is your brother Ernest? We are both engaged to be married to your brother Ernest, so it is a matter of some importance to us to know where your brother Ernest is at present.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen—Cecily—it is very painful for me to be forced to speak the truth. It is the first time in my life that I have ever been reduced to such a painful position, and I am really quite inexperienced in doing anything of the kind. However, I will tell you quite frankly that I have no brother Ernest. I have no brother at all. I never had a brother in my life, and I certainly have not the smallest intention of ever having one in the future.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: No brother at all?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: None!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Had you never a brother of any kind?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Never. Not even of any kind.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am afraid it is quite clear, Cecily, that neither of us is engaged to be married to any one.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: It is not a very pleasant position for a young girl suddenly to find herself in. Is it?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Let us go into the house. They will hardly venture to come after us there.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: No, men are so cowardly, aren’t they?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: This ghastly state of things is what you call Bunburying, I suppose?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, and a perfectly wonderful Bunbury it is. The most wonderful Bunbury I have ever had in my life.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, you’ve no right whatsoever to Bunbury here.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That is absurd. One has a right to Bunbury anywhere one chooses. Every serious Bunburyist knows that.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Serious Bunburyist! Good heavens!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, one must be serious about something, if one wants to have any amusement in life. I happen to be serious about Bunburying. What on earth you are serious about I haven’t got the remotest idea. About everything, I should fancy. You have such an absolutely trivial nature.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, the only small satisfaction I have in the whole of this wretched business is that your friend Bunbury is quite exploded. You won’t be able to run down to the country quite so often as you used to do, dear Algy. And a very good thing too.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Your brother is a little off colour, isn’t he, dear Jack? You won’t be able to disappear to London quite so frequently as your wicked custom was. And not a bad thing either.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: As for your conduct towards Miss Cardew, I must say that your taking in a sweet, simple, innocent girl like that is quite inexcusable. To say nothing of the fact that she is my ward.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I can see no possible defence at all for your deceiving a brilliant, clever, thoroughly experienced young lady like Miss Fairfax. To say nothing of the fact that she is my cousin.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I wanted to be engaged to Gwendolen, that is all. I love her.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, I simply wanted to be engaged to Cecily. I adore her.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: There is certainly no chance of your marrying Miss Cardew.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I don’t think there is much likelihood, Jack, of you and Miss Fairfax being united.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, that is no business of yours.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: If it was my business, I wouldn’t talk about it.  It is very vulgar to talk about one’s business. Only people like stock-brokers do that, and then merely at dinner parties.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: How can you sit there, calmly eating muffins when we are in this horrible trouble, I can’t make out. You seem to me to be perfectly heartless.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, I can’t eat muffins in an agitated manner. The butter would probably get on my cuffs. One should always eat muffins quite calmly. It is the only way to eat them.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I say it’s perfectly heartless your eating muffins at all, under the circumstances.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: When I am in trouble, eating is the only thing that consoles me. Indeed, when I am in really great trouble, as any one who knows me intimately will tell you, I refuse everything except food and drink. At the present moment I am eating muffins because I am unhappy. Besides, I am particularly fond of muffins.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Well, that is no reason why you should eat them all in that greedy way.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I wish you would have tea-cake instead. I don’t like tea-cake.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Good heavens! I suppose a man may eat his own muffins in his own garden.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: But you have just said it was perfectly heartless to eat muffins.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I said it was perfectly heartless of you, under the circumstances. That is a very different thing.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That may be. But the muffins are the same.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Algy, I wish to goodness you would go.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You can’t possibly ask me to go without having some dinner. It’s absurd. I never go without my dinner. No one ever does, except vegetarians and people like that. Besides I have just made arrangements with Dr. Chasuble to be christened at a quarter to six under the name of Ernest.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My dear fellow, the sooner you give up that nonsense the better. I made arrangements this morning with Dr. Chasuble to be christened myself at 5.30, and I naturally will take the name of Ernest. Gwendolen would wish it. We can’t both be christened Ernest. It’s absurd. Besides, I have a perfect right to be christened if I like. There is no evidence at all that I have ever been christened by anybody. I should think it extremely probable I never was, and so does Dr. Chasuble. It is entirely different in your case. You have been christened already.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, but I have not been christened for years.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, but you have been christened. That is the important thing.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Quite so. So I know my constitution can stand it. If you are not quite sure about your ever having been christened, I must say I think it rather dangerous your venturing on it now. It might make you very unwell. You can hardly have forgotten that some one very closely connected with you was very nearly carried off this week in Paris by a severe chill.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, but you said yourself that a severe chill was not hereditary.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It usen’t to be, I know—but I daresay it is now. Science is always making wonderful improvements in things.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Oh, that is nonsense; you are always talking nonsense.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Jack, you are at the muffins again! I wish you wouldn’t. There are only two left.  I told you I was particularly fond of muffins.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: But I hate tea-cake.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Why on earth then do you allow tea-cake to be served up for your guests? What ideas you have of hospitality!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Algernon! I have already told you to go. I don’t want you here. Why don’t you go!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I haven’t quite finished my tea yet! and there is still one muffin left.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: The fact that they did not follow us at once into the house, as any one else would have done, seems to me to show that they have some sense of shame left.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: They have been eating muffins. That looks like repentance.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: They don’t seem to notice us at all. Couldn’t you cough?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: But I haven’t got a cough.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: They’re looking at us. What effrontery!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: They’re approaching. That’s very forward of them.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Let us preserve a dignified silence.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Certainly. It’s the only thing to do now.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: This dignified silence seems to produce an unpleasant effect.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: A most distasteful one.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: But we will not be the first to speak.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Certainly not.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Mr. Worthing, I have something very particular to ask you. Much depends on your reply.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen, your common sense is invaluable. Mr. Moncrieff, kindly answer me the following question. Why did you pretend to be my guardian’s brother?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: In order that I might have an opportunity of meeting you.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: That certainly seems a satisfactory explanation, does it not?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Yes, dear, if you can believe him.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I don’t. But that does not affect the wonderful beauty of his answer.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: True. In matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity is the vital thing. Mr. Worthing, what explanation can you offer to me for pretending to have a brother? Was it in order that you might have an opportunity of coming up to town to see me as often as possible?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Can you doubt it, Miss Fairfax?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I have the gravest doubts upon the subject. But I intend to crush them. This is not the moment for German scepticism.  Their explanations appear to be quite satisfactory, especially Mr. Worthing’s. That seems to me to have the stamp of truth upon it.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I am more than content with what Mr. Moncrieff said. His voice alone inspires one with absolute credulity.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Then you think we should forgive them?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Yes. I mean no.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: True! I had forgotten. There are principles at stake that one cannot surrender. Which of us should tell them? The task is not a pleasant one.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Could we not both speak at the same time?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: An excellent idea! I nearly always speak at the same time as other people. Will you take the time from me?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Certainly.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: and Cecily  Your Christian names are still an insuperable barrier. That is all!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: and Algernon  Our Christian names! Is that all? But we are going to be christened this afternoon.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: For my sake you are prepared to do this terrible thing?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: I am.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: To please me you are ready to face this fearful ordeal?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I am!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: How absurd to talk of the equality of the sexes! Where questions of self-sacrifice are concerned, men are infinitely beyond us.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: We are.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: They have moments of physical courage of which we women know absolutely nothing.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Darling!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Darling!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Ahem! Ahem! Lady Bracknell!
lines.name: Merriman

lines.text: Good heavens!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Gwendolen! What does this mean?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Merely that I am engaged to be married to Mr. Worthing, mamma.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Come here. Sit down. Sit down immediately. Hesitation of any kind is a sign of mental decay in the young, of physical weakness in the old.  Apprised, sir, of my daughter’s sudden flight by her trusty maid, whose confidence I purchased by means of a small coin, I followed her at once by a luggage train. Her unhappy father is, I am glad to say, under the impression that she is attending a more than usually lengthy lecture by the University Extension Scheme on the Influence of a permanent income on Thought. I do not propose to undeceive him. Indeed I have never undeceived him on any question. I would consider it wrong. But of course, you will clearly understand that all communication between yourself and my daughter must cease immediately from this moment. On this point, as indeed on all points, I am firm.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I am engaged to be married to Gwendolen Lady Bracknell!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You are nothing of the kind, sir. And now, as regards Algernon! . . . Algernon!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: May I ask if it is in this house that your invalid friend Mr. Bunbury resides?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Oh! No! Bunbury doesn’t live here. Bunbury is somewhere else at present. In fact, Bunbury is dead,
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Dead! When did Mr. Bunbury die? His death must have been extremely sudden.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Oh! I killed Bunbury this afternoon. I mean poor Bunbury died this afternoon.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: What did he die of?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Bunbury? Oh, he was quite exploded.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Exploded! Was he the victim of a revolutionary outrage? I was not aware that Mr. Bunbury was interested in social legislation. If so, he is well punished for his morbidity.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: My dear Aunt Augusta, I mean he was found out! The doctors found out that Bunbury could not live, that is what I mean—so Bunbury died.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: He seems to have had great confidence in the opinion of his physicians. I am glad, however, that he made up his mind at the last to some definite course of action, and acted under proper medical advice. And now that we have finally got rid of this Mr. Bunbury, may I ask, Mr. Worthing, who is that young person whose hand my nephew Algernon is now holding in what seems to me a peculiarly unnecessary manner?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: That lady is Miss Cecily Cardew, my ward.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am engaged to be married to Cecily, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I beg your pardon?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Mr. Moncrieff and I are engaged to be married, Lady Bracknell.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: I do not know whether there is anything peculiarly exciting in the air of this particular part of Hertfordshire, but the number of engagements that go on seems to me considerably above the proper average that statistics have laid down for our guidance. I think some preliminary inquiry on my part would not be out of place. Mr. Worthing, is Miss Cardew at all connected with any of the larger railway stations in London? I merely desire information. Until yesterday I had no idea that there were any families or persons whose origin was a Terminus.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Miss Cardew is the grand-daughter of the late Mr. Thomas Cardew of 149 Belgrave Square, S.W.; Gervase Park, Dorking, Surrey; and the Sporran, Fifeshire, N.B.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That sounds not unsatisfactory. Three addresses always inspire confidence, even in tradesmen. But what proof have I of their authenticity?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I have carefully preserved the Court Guides of the period. They are open to your inspection, Lady Bracknell.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I have known strange errors in that publication.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Miss Cardew’s family solicitors are Messrs. Markby, Markby, and Markby.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Markby, Markby, and Markby? A firm of the very highest position in their profession. Indeed I am told that one of the Mr. Markby’s is occasionally to be seen at dinner parties. So far I am satisfied.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: How extremely kind of you, Lady Bracknell! I have also in my possession, you will be pleased to hear, certificates of Miss Cardew’s birth, baptism, whooping cough, registration, vaccination, confirmation, and the measles; both the German and the English variety.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Ah! A life crowded with incident, I see; though perhaps somewhat too exciting for a young girl. I am not myself in favour of premature experiences.  Gwendolen! the time approaches for our departure. We have not a moment to lose. As a matter of form, Mr. Worthing, I had better ask you if Miss Cardew has any little fortune?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Oh! about a hundred and thirty thousand pounds in the Funds. That is all. Goodbye, Lady Bracknell. So pleased to have seen you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: A moment, Mr. Worthing. A hundred and thirty thousand pounds! And in the Funds! Miss Cardew seems to me a most attractive young lady, now that I look at her. Few girls of the present day have any really solid qualities, any of the qualities that last, and improve with time. We live, I regret to say, in an age of surfaces.  Come over here, dear.  Pretty child! your dress is sadly simple, and your hair seems almost as Nature might have left it. But we can soon alter all that. A thoroughly experienced French maid produces a really marvellous result in a very brief space of time. I remember recommending one to young Lady Lancing, and after three months her own husband did not know her.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: And after six months nobody knew her.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Kindly turn round, sweet child.  No, the side view is what I want.  Yes, quite as I expected. There are distinct social possibilities in your profile. The two weak points in our age are its want of principle and its want of profile. The chin a little higher, dear. Style largely depends on the way the chin is worn. They are worn very high, just at present. Algernon!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, Aunt Augusta!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: There are distinct social possibilities in Miss Cardew’s profile.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Cecily is the sweetest, dearest, prettiest girl in the whole world. And I don’t care twopence about social possibilities.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Never speak disrespectfully of Society, Algernon. Only people who can’t get into it do that.  Dear child, of course you know that Algernon has nothing but his debts to depend upon. But I do not approve of mercenary marriages. When I married Lord Bracknell I had no fortune of any kind. But I never dreamed for a moment of allowing that to stand in my way. Well, I suppose I must give my consent.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Cecily, you may kiss me!
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thank you, Lady Bracknell.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You may also address me as Aunt Augusta for the future.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: The marriage, I think, had better take place quite soon.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Thank you, Aunt Augusta.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: To speak frankly, I am not in favour of long engagements. They give people the opportunity of finding out each other’s character before marriage, which I think is never advisable.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I beg your pardon for interrupting you, Lady Bracknell, but this engagement is quite out of the question. I am Miss Cardew’s guardian, and she cannot marry without my consent until she comes of age. That consent I absolutely decline to give.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Upon what grounds may I ask? Algernon is an extremely, I may almost say an ostentatiously, eligible young man. He has nothing, but he looks everything. What more can one desire?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: It pains me very much to have to speak frankly to you, Lady Bracknell, about your nephew, but the fact is that I do not approve at all of his moral character. I suspect him of being untruthful.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Untruthful! My nephew Algernon? Impossible! He is an Oxonian.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I fear there can be no possible doubt about the matter. This afternoon during my temporary absence in London on an important question of romance, he obtained admission to my house by means of the false pretence of being my brother. Under an assumed name he drank, I’ve just been informed by my butler, an entire pint bottle of my Perrier-Jouet, Brut, ’89; wine I was specially reserving for myself. Continuing his disgraceful deception, he succeeded in the course of the afternoon in alienating the affections of my only ward. He subsequently stayed to tea, and devoured every single muffin. And what makes his conduct all the more heartless is, that he was perfectly well aware from the first that I have no brother, that I never had a brother, and that I don’t intend to have a brother, not even of any kind. I distinctly told him so myself yesterday afternoon.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Ahem! Mr. Worthing, after careful consideration I have decided entirely to overlook my nephew’s conduct to you.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: That is very generous of you, Lady Bracknell. My own decision, however, is unalterable. I decline to give my consent.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Come here, sweet child.  How old are you, dear?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Well, I am really only eighteen, but I always admit to twenty when I go to evening parties.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: You are perfectly right in making some slight alteration. Indeed, no woman should ever be quite accurate about her age. It looks so calculating . . .  Eighteen, but admitting to twenty at evening parties. Well, it will not be very long before you are of age and free from the restraints of tutelage. So I don’t think your guardian’s consent is, after all, a matter of any importance.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Pray excuse me, Lady Bracknell, for interrupting you again, but it is only fair to tell you that according to the terms of her grandfather’s will Miss Cardew does not come legally of age till she is thirty-five.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That does not seem to me to be a grave objection. Thirty-five is a very attractive age. London society is full of women of the very highest birth who have, of their own free choice, remained thirty-five for years. Lady Dumbleton is an instance in point. To my own knowledge she has been thirty-five ever since she arrived at the age of forty, which was many years ago now. I see no reason why our dear Cecily should not be even still more attractive at the age you mention than she is at present. There will be a large accumulation of property.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Algy, could you wait for me till I was thirty-five?
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Of course I could, Cecily. You know I could.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Yes, I felt it instinctively, but I couldn’t wait all that time. I hate waiting even five minutes for anybody. It always makes me rather cross. I am not punctual myself, I know, but I do like punctuality in others, and waiting, even to be married, is quite out of the question.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Then what is to be done, Cecily?
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: I don’t know, Mr. Moncrieff.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: My dear Mr. Worthing, as Miss Cardew states positively that she cannot wait till she is thirty-five—a remark which I am bound to say seems to me to show a somewhat impatient nature—I would beg of you to reconsider your decision.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: But my dear Lady Bracknell, the matter is entirely in your own hands. The moment you consent to my marriage with Gwendolen, I will most gladly allow your nephew to form an alliance with my ward.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You must be quite aware that what you propose is out of the question.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Then a passionate celibacy is all that any of us can look forward to.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: That is not the destiny I propose for Gwendolen. Algernon, of course, can choose for himself.  Come, dear,  we have already missed five, if not six, trains. To miss any more might expose us to comment on the platform.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Everything is quite ready for the christenings.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: The christenings, sir! Is not that somewhat premature?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Both these gentlemen have expressed a desire for immediate baptism.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: At their age? The idea is grotesque and irreligious! Algernon, I forbid you to be baptized. I will not hear of such excesses. Lord Bracknell would be highly displeased if he learned that that was the way in which you wasted your time and money.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Am I to understand then that there are to be no christenings at all this afternoon?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I don’t think that, as things are now, it would be of much practical value to either of us, Dr. Chasuble.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am grieved to hear such sentiments from you, Mr. Worthing. They savour of the heretical views of the Anabaptists, views that I have completely refuted in four of my unpublished sermons. However, as your present mood seems to be one peculiarly secular, I will return to the church at once. Indeed, I have just been informed by the pew-opener that for the last hour and a half Miss Prism has been waiting for me in the vestry.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Miss Prism! Did I hear you mention a Miss Prism?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, Lady Bracknell. I am on my way to join her.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Pray allow me to detain you for a moment. This matter may prove to be one of vital importance to Lord Bracknell and myself. Is this Miss Prism a female of repellent aspect, remotely connected with education?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: She is the most cultivated of ladies, and the very picture of respectability.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: It is obviously the same person. May I ask what position she holds in your household?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: I am a celibate, madam.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Miss Prism, Lady Bracknell, has been for the last three years Miss Cardew’s esteemed governess and valued companion.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: In spite of what I hear of her, I must see her at once. Let her be sent for.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: She approaches; she is nigh.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I was told you expected me in the vestry, dear Canon. I have been waiting for you there for an hour and three-quarters.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Prism!  Come here, Prism!  Prism! Where is that baby?  Twenty-eight years ago, Prism, you left Lord Bracknell’s house, Number 104, Upper Grosvenor Street, in charge of a perambulator that contained a baby of the male sex. You never returned. A few weeks later, through the elaborate investigations of the Metropolitan police, the perambulator was discovered at midnight, standing by itself in a remote corner of Bayswater. It contained the manuscript of a three-volume novel of more than usually revolting sentimentality.  But the baby was not there!  Prism! Where is that baby?
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Lady Bracknell, I admit with shame that I do not know. I only wish I did. The plain facts of the case are these. On the morning of the day you mention, a day that is for ever branded on my memory, I prepared as usual to take the baby out in its perambulator. I had also with me a somewhat old, but capacious hand-bag in which I had intended to place the manuscript of a work of fiction that I had written during my few unoccupied hours. In a moment of mental abstraction, for which I never can forgive myself, I deposited the manuscript in the basinette, and placed the baby in the hand-bag.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: But where did you deposit the hand-bag?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Do not ask me, Mr. Worthing.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Miss Prism, this is a matter of no small importance to me. I insist on knowing where you deposited the hand-bag that contained that infant.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I left it in the cloak-room of one of the larger railway stations in London.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: What railway station?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Victoria. The Brighton line.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: I must retire to my room for a moment. Gwendolen, wait here for me.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: If you are not too long, I will wait here for you all my life.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: What do you think this means, Lady Bracknell?
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I dare not even suspect, Dr. Chasuble. I need hardly tell you that in families of high position strange coincidences are not supposed to occur. They are hardly considered the thing.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Uncle Jack seems strangely agitated.
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Your guardian has a very emotional nature.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: This noise is extremely unpleasant. It sounds as if he was having an argument. I dislike arguments of any kind. They are always vulgar, and often convincing.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: It has stopped now.
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: I wish he would arrive at some conclusion.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: This suspense is terrible. I hope it will last.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Is this the hand-bag, Miss Prism? Examine it carefully before you speak. The happiness of more than one life depends on your answer.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: It seems to be mine. Yes, here is the injury it received through the upsetting of a Gower Street omnibus in younger and happier days. Here is the stain on the lining caused by the explosion of a temperance beverage, an incident that occurred at Leamington. And here, on the lock, are my initials. I had forgotten that in an extravagant mood I had had them placed there. The bag is undoubtedly mine. I am delighted to have it so unexpectedly restored to me. It has been a great inconvenience being without it all these years.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Miss Prism, more is restored to you than this hand-bag. I was the baby you placed in it.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: You?
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Yes . . . mother!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Mr. Worthing! I am unmarried!
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Unmarried! I do not deny that is a serious blow. But after all, who has the right to cast a stone against one who has suffered? Cannot repentance wipe out an act of folly? Why should there be one law for men, and another for women? Mother, I forgive you.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Mr. Worthing, there is some error.  There is the lady who can tell you who you really are.
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Lady Bracknell, I hate to seem inquisitive, but would you kindly inform me who I am?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I am afraid that the news I have to give you will not altogether please you. You are the son of my poor sister, Mrs. Moncrieff, and consequently Algernon’s elder brother.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Algy’s elder brother! Then I have a brother after all. I knew I had a brother! I always said I had a brother! Cecily,—how could you have ever doubted that I had a brother?  Dr. Chasuble, my unfortunate brother. Miss Prism, my unfortunate brother. Gwendolen, my unfortunate brother. Algy, you young scoundrel, you will have to treat me with more respect in the future. You have never behaved to me like a brother in all your life.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Well, not till to-day, old boy, I admit. I did my best, however, though I was out of practice.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: My own! But what own are you? What is your Christian name, now that you have become some one else?
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Good heavens! . . . I had quite forgotten that point. Your decision on the subject of my name is irrevocable, I suppose?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I never change, except in my affections.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: What a noble nature you have, Gwendolen!
lines.name: Cecily

lines.text: Then the question had better be cleared up at once. Aunt Augusta, a moment. At the time when Miss Prism left me in the hand-bag, had I been christened already?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Every luxury that money could buy, including christening, had been lavished on you by your fond and doting parents.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Then I was christened! That is settled. Now, what name was I given? Let me know the worst.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Being the eldest son you were naturally christened after your father.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Yes, but what was my father’s Christian name?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I cannot at the present moment recall what the General’s Christian name was. But I have no doubt he had one. He was eccentric, I admit. But only in later years. And that was the result of the Indian climate, and marriage, and indigestion, and other things of that kind.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Algy! Can’t you recollect what our father’s Christian name was?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My dear boy, we were never even on speaking terms. He died before I was a year old.
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: His name would appear in the Army Lists of the period, I suppose, Aunt Augusta?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: The General was essentially a man of peace, except in his domestic life. But I have no doubt his name would appear in any military directory.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: The Army Lists of the last forty years are here. These delightful records should have been my constant study.  M. Generals . . . Mallam, Maxbohm, Magley, what ghastly names they have—Markby, Migsby, Mobbs, Moncrieff! Lieutenant 1840, Captain, Lieutenant-Colonel, Colonel, General 1869, Christian names, Ernest John.  I always told you, Gwendolen, my name was Ernest, didn’t I? Well, it is Ernest after all. I mean it naturally is Ernest.
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Yes, I remember now that the General was called Ernest, I knew I had some particular reason for disliking the name.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: Ernest! My own Ernest! I felt from the first that you could have no other name!
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: Gwendolen, it is a terrible thing for a man to find out suddenly that all his life he has been speaking nothing but the truth. Can you forgive me?
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: I can. For I feel that you are sure to change.
lines.name: Gwendolen

lines.text: My own one!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: Lætitia!
lines.name: Chasuble

lines.text: Frederick! At last!
lines.name: Miss Prism

lines.text: Cecily!  At last!
lines.name: Algernon

lines.text: Gwendolen!  At last!
lines.name: Jack

lines.text: My nephew, you seem to be displaying signs of triviality.
lines.name: Lady Bracknell

lines.text: On the contrary, Aunt Augusta, I’ve now realised for the first time in my life the vital Importance of Being Earnest.
lines.name: Jack
